QUOTE OF THE DAY"Just because something doesn't 
      do what you planned it to do doesn't mean it's useless." - Thomas 
      A. Edison 



DID YOU KNOW?Chocolate manufacturers 
      currently use 40 percent of the world's almonds and 20 percent of the 
      world's peanuts. 



TONIGHT ON THE CBS EVENING 
      NEWSHere is an early preview of what we are 
      planning for tonight's CBS EVENING NEWS from Anchor and Managing Editor, 
      Katie Couric... Hi everyone, I'll be 
      anchoring a special hour-long broadcast tonight from Blacksburg, Virginia, 
      where earlier today a gunman opened fire multiple times at the Virginia 
      Tech University, resulting in the deadliest campus massacre in U.S. 
      history. Our team of correspondents will bring you complete coverage. 
      We will start by telling you about the incidents that began 
      unfolding at 7:15 this morning in one of the largest residence halls on 
      the Virginia Tech campus and continued two hours later at Norris Hall, an 
      engineering building. By late morning, at least 33 on campus were dead. President Bush said 
      he was "horrified" by the news of the shooting, and expressed his sympathy 
      for the victims and their families. Thalia Assuras will talk with 
      some of the students who survived the shooting and have more eyewitness 
      accounts. Daniel Sieberg, our Science and Technology 
      Correspondent, will detail how the university and the students who study 
      there used Internet communications to keep one another informed as the 
      tragedy unfolded. And in the wake of such a massacre, it is 
      natural to ask "could this have been prevented?" Hari Sreenivasan 
      will report on the state of security on campuses around the country. 
      In the meantime, residents of the Northeast are coping with the 
      remnants of a massive storm that hit over the weekend, bringing record 
      rainfall and strong winds. By Monday afternoon, much of the East Coast was 
      still under water and hundreds of thousands of people were without 
      electricity. Nancy Cordes will have the story. The National 
      Urban League is releasing a report tomorrow that will show that black men 
      in America don't have many of the same privileges as other citizens. We'll 
      have the study's findings tonight. I hope you'll join us. 
      In the meantime, stay updated on news out of Virginia by visiting 
      CBSNews.com. Thanks, Katie For more 
      information on these stories, please click on the following links:
At Least 31 Killed In Va. Tech Massacre Click 
      Here Flooded Homes, Power Outages On East Coast Click 
      Here And here's a look at one of the stories we're working 
      on for Tuesday's broadcast: We'll have all the latest on the 
      school massacre in Virginia. And Attorney General Alberto Gonzales goes to 
      Capitol Hill to fight for his job. That story and much more, Tuesday, on 
      the CBS Evening News. If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 



TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANDave sits down with talk show 
      host/actress Kelly Ripa AND actor Simon Pegg... Plus, comedian Jim Short! 
      



TUESDAY 
      MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOWHarry Smith 
      anchors THE EARLY SHOW from Blacksburg, VA. 
      Russ Mitchell and Maggie Rodriguez, of 
      our Miami affiliate WFOR, anchor from New York. Julie 
      Chen anchors from Los Angeles. Dave Price will 
      bring us the weather. Hannah Storm is off. 
      THE EARLY SHOW WILL HAVE SPECIAL COVERAGE OF 
      "MASSACRE AT VIRGINIA TECH." Here is a look at some of the stories 
      we will be focusing on: VIRGINIA TECH LATEST: On Monday, 
      Virginia Tech was the scene of horrible massacre. With at least 30 dead 
      and close to 22 injured, it is the worst campus shooting in United States 
      history. Police say the gunman killed a victim in a dorm, and then later 
      opened fire in a classroom where most of the fatalities occurred. CBS News 
      Security Correspondent Bob Orr will have the latest on 
      the gunman and what exactly happened at Virginia Tech. LOU 
      DOBBS ON SCHOOL VIOLENCE: Lou Dobbs will offer his take on school 
      violence in his second weekly commentary. HISTORY OF 
      SCHOOL SHOOTINGS: School shootings are nothing new. In fact, 
      before the massacre at Virginia Tech, a shooting in 1966 was the most 
      devastating in United States history. Now, we once again are forced to 
      take a look at why such horrific violence is happening and has continued 
      to happen for decades. VIRGINIA TECH TRAUMA: 
      Clinical psychologist and Early Show Contributor 
      Robin Goodman will join us to take a look at the trauma 
      the students at Virginia Tech will be experiencing. How can they begin the 
      healing process? Also, we'll ask Dr. Goodman about the 
      trauma the shooting may be causing your children at home. Should they 
      watch the news with you? And is it good for them to do so? We'll take a 
      look. IS YOUR CHILD SAFE?: EARLY SHOW 
      National Correspondent Hattie Kaufman will take a look at 
      campus security. Is your child safe? We'll tell you what questions you 
      need to be sure to ask on any campus tour. If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
